description.narrative: Cacanska Banka ad Cacak (CBC or the Bank) has a long tradition in Western Serbia operating since 1956 as a regional bank, covering mainly Central and Western Serbia through a network of 25 organizational units in 21 towns headquartered in Cacak, an industrial center in Western Serbia. The Bank employs 396 people. It is a universal bank offering a full range of banking services to its retail and corporate/SME clients, with SMEs representing over 80% of the Banks portfolio. Although CBC is a small bank, it holds a leading position in servicing SMEs in Western Serbia. The Project consists of a potential equity investment of up to 20% of CBC and senior loan facility of up to EUR7 million. It is a joint IFI effort aimed at strengthening the Bank''s capital base, and thereby improving its competitive position and enabling it to bear likely stresses on asset quality in view of the financial crisis. It is also expected to facilitate the eventual sale of the Bank to a strategic investor once normalcy returns. IFC will provide five year Senior Loan with a purpose of on lending to small and medium size enterprises, subject to the capital investment.

The Project is expected to have a high development impact. It will: - enable CBC to expand its lending to SMEs in the region that had limited access to finance from the banking sector historically and who will need more support given the effect of global crisis in Serbia. Central and Western Serbia region has a high concentration of SMEs, which play a critical role in the country''s economic growth and employment. - strengthen the capital base and adequacy of the Bank and demonstrate the ability of a Serbian locally-owned bank to attract investments from international institutional investors in difficult financing times and thereby help the Bank to meet difficult asset quality and liquidity challenges going forward. - will enable economic growth and job protection in less developed regions in Serbia. - advance capacity and institution building of the Bank through the IFC''s nominee possible involvement in the Bank''s Board of Directors; and - facilitate the eventual sale of the Bank to a strategic investor.
